ww_b2e67e63be49bf0a.text:
[Spark:] Sure Ladies I must needs say th' instinct of this herb hath wrought in this Gentleman such a divine influence of good words, excellent discourse, admirable invention, incoparable wit: why I tell ye, when he talks, wisdom stands a mile off and dares not come near him, for fear a should shame her: but before a did use this Tobacco, a was the arrantest Woodcock that ever I saw.
[Petoune:] Indeed I was a very silly fellow.
[Ruffell:] Nay you were an arrant ass.
[Petoune:] Sure I was a fool.
[Knight:] Nay, you were a most monstrous puppy.
[Petoune:] Indeed I was an Idiot, a very Idiot.
[Piso:] By this light thou wert a most egregious coxcomb.
[Petoune:] Indeed I was, indeed I was.

ww_b0f29d01fdeb9847.text:
[Ruffell:] Come signeur, put your hand to the pipe.
[Susan:] First you shall never while you live offer Lady or Gentlewoman an empty pipe.
[Petoune:] Never.
[Susan:] Secondly, you shall never make Tobacco your Idol, taking it in a morning before you say your prayers.
[Petoune:] Never.
[Susan:] Thirdly, you shall never in the praise of Tobacco disclose or dispraise by the way of making comparisons, the secrets of Ladies, or Gentlewomen, as repeating their distilled waters, their censing oils, or their smoothing unguents.
[Spark:] To this you swear.
[Petoune:] Most willingly.
[Susan:] Fourthly, you shall never come with your squibs & smoke-squirts amongst Ladies and Gentlewomen, flinging out fume at your Nostrils, as a whale doth salt-water, unless you be entreated by them.
[Petoune:] Never.
[Susan:] Fiftly, you shall presently convey yourself out of our company, never to come more near us, unless you be sent for.
[Petoune:] Never?
[Susan:] No never: so, let him kiss the pipe.

ww_e06a91f5588bc615.text:
[Spark:] What art?
[Fleer:] Poor.
[Ruffell:] Dost mean to live in this town?
[Fleer:] I'd be loth to die in't.
[Knight:] In what country wert born?
[Fleer:] In none.
[Knight:] Where then?
[Fleer:] In a Town.
[Knight:] What nation art?
[Fleer:] An Italian:
[Knight:] O then thou canst make glasses.
[Fleer:] Ay, and as wisemen as you Asses too, O are you there Piso? your father is my good Lord, but no more of that yet.
[Spark:] Why Signior, I hope you wonnot swagger?
[Fleer:] No, nor I care not greatly for them that do, for your swaggerer is but like your walking spur, a gingles much but he'll nev'r prick.
[Knight:] Why art so melancholy?
[Susan:] I'll hold my life he is in love with some waiting Gentlewoman.
[Fleer:] He's a mad fellow will love any of you all, longer then a pissing while.
[Piso:] Why camst thou out of Italy into England?
[Fleer:] Because England would not come into Italy to me?
[Piso:] Why art sad?
[Fleer:] Because I have cause.
[Piso:] Who dost follow?
[Fleer:] My nose.
[Spark:] Who dost serve?
[Fleer:] God.
[Ruff:! Who art towards?
[Fleer:] He that's before me.
[Spark:] What dost want?
[Fleer:] Money.
[Spark:] Nothing else?
[Fleer:] Yes.
[Spark:] What?
[Fleer:] A good service.
[Spark:] Shall I prefer thee?
[Fleer:] I cannot tell, tis as I like the man.
[Spark:] Nai't shall be to a couple of Gentlewomen of thine own Country.
[...]
[Spark:] What's thy name?
[Fleer:] Fleer.
[Spark:] What's thy profession?
[Fleer:] I have ever been a Courtier.
[Spark:] A Courtier! come Gentlemen, I like this fellow so well that I'll prefer him straight.

ww_01d461f0bd230f15.text: [Fleer:] So I thought indeed, you cannot poison so well as we Italians, but you'll find a means to bring a man out of his life as soon.

ww_3f701b24fd7cb382.text:
[Florida:] Faith well Madam, were not your Citizens, such heavy head fellows:
[Felecia:] Thats a sign they are no drunkards.
[Fleer:] Indeed Madam, drink lightens the head, the heart, the heels, the pot, the purse, but it makes heavy chamberpots, full bowels, and foul rooms enough.

ww_a3522661d416b9bc.text:
[Florida:] But how dost like the Court Fleer?
[Fleer:] Well enough, if they did not catch their meat so; it comes no sooner from Table, but t'one fellow has a fat Duck by the rump, t'other a slippery Eel by the tail, and an old Courtier that best knew the tricks on't, was mumbling of a Cunny in a corner alone by himself.

ww_526c668bf1ae02c0.text:
[Ruffell:] I did pray oftener when I was an Englishman, but I have not prayed often, I must confess since I was a Britain: but doost hear Fleer? canst tell me if an Englishman were in debt, whether a Britain must pay it or no?
[Fleer:] No, question-less no.
[Ruffell:] I'm glad of that, I hope some honest statute will come shortly, and wipe out all my scores.

ww_18c75be3ff535f61.text:
[Fleer:] His love to her? what Signor, in love with my Ladies Antient?
[Sparke:] Why her Ancient?
[Fleer:] Because she carries her colours for her, but tis in a box: but signor you shall have a good match on't, though she be not rich, yet she's an ancient woman and is able to get her living, by midwifery, and I can tell ye tis not the worst trade going, considering how young and old, and all do their good wills to set them a work, and tis a good hearing, better they get then the Lawyers, for your midwives live by the agreement between party and party, & the falling in of lovers, but the Lawyers live by the falling out of friends.
[Petoune:] I pray sir what may she be worth?
[Fleer:] Worth? let me see, she hath three yellow periwigs of her own: she hath a Pan with a short silver handle about the length of a Barbers syringe: she has a Looking-glass too, but that has plaid the prodigal Citizen with lier, tis broken, and much other goods of the same nature.
[Sparke:] But come Signor, how will you woo her?
[Petoune:] I will tell her she is so wise, that neither age nor time could cousen her of beauty.
[Fleer:] And by my faith that will doe well.
[Petoune:] I will tell her that I love her most for the whiteness of her skin.
[Fleer:] But you may not say the sweetness of her breath, for that stinks.
[Petoune:] I will praise the smallness of her fingers.
[Fleer:] But I assure you, you may better praise the length of her nails.
[Petoune:] I am afraid that being old she has a dry hand.
[Fleer:] That's certain, but she has a very moist nose, you may praise her for that [...]

ww_ce2cd24cf9795365.text:
[Ruffle:] What Gallants use to come to your house?
[Fleer:] All sorts, all nations, and all trades: there is first Master Gallant your Britaine, Master Metheglins your Welshman, Mousieur Mushroome the Frenchman: Signior Fumada the Spaniard, Master Oscabath the Irishman: and Master Shamrock his Lackey, O and Master Slopdragon the Dutchman. Then for your Tradesmen, there comes first Master Saluberrimum the Physican, Master Smooth the Silkman, Master Thimble the Tailor, Master Blade the Cutler, and Master Rowell the Spurrier: but Master Match the Gunner of Tower-hill comes often [...].

ww_bbb3b406f9313227.text:
[Fleer:] But believe me my little Gallants, ye play the Boys well.
[Nan:] Well? why I'll tell thee, I have played the boy so long as I am chang'd into the nature of a boy, I'll go to span counter with any page in Europe, for his best garters I can tell bawdy tales, drink drunk, brag, swear, and lie with any Lackey in the town.
[Susan:] I can man a punk to a play, or slander any Gentlewoman as well as any Inns of Court puny, I can as well as he, swear such a Lady is in love with me, and such a Citizen's Daughter would have come to bed to me, when all shall be as true as thy Ladies are honest.

ww_50a5073fd47fdca3.text:
[Macbeth:] Who can be wise, amazed, temp’rate, and furious,
Loyal, and neutral, in a moment? No man.
Th' expedition of my violent love
Outrun the pauser, reason. Here lay Duncan,
His silver skin laced with his golden blood,
And his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature
For ruin's wasteful entrance; there the murderers,
Steeped in the colors of their trade, their daggers
Unmannerly breeched with gore. Who could refrain
That had a heart to love, and in that heart
Courage to make 's love known?

ww_17a2e041f97118ed.text:
[Doctor Glister:] And from what good exercise come you three.
[Gerardine:] From a play, where we saw most excellent Sampson excell the whole world in gate carrying.
[Dryfat:] Was it performed by the youths.
[Lypsalve:] By youths: why I tell thee we saw Sampson , and J hope 'tis not for youths to play Sampson : Believe it we saw Sampson bear the Town gates on his neck, from the lower to the upper stage, with that life and admirable accord, that it shall never be equalled (unless the whole new livery of Porters set their shoulders) [...].

I'll bring you to my sister Somerfield.

ww_75ebe0ccef5eb2da.text:
[Scudmore:] Whereas you write, my fortunes and my birth
Made above yours, may be a real cause
That I must leave you, know thou worthiest man,
Thou hast a soul, whose plenteous wealth supplies
All the lean wants blind Chance hath dealt to thee.
Yet could I think, the Goddess from all their store,
Who ne'er knew indigence unto their will,
Would (out of all their stock of Virtue left,
Or out of all new graces they can make)
Make such another piece as Scudmore is,
Then might he justly fear; but otherwise,
Sooner the Masculine Element of Fire,
Shall flame his Pyramids down to the Earth;
Sooner her Mountains shall swell up to Heaven,
Or softest April showers quench fires in Hell;
Sooner shall Stars from this Circumference,
Drop like false fairy exhalation,
Then I be false to vows made unto thee;
In whom, ought ne'er a fault: I ne'er could see,
But that you doubted once my constancy.

ww_754c2adf8b76688f.text:
[Scudamore:] How sweetly does your friendship play with mine
And with a simple subtlety, steals my heart
Out of my bosom.

ww_3470b342ee2f1dd3.text:
[Nevill:] [...] farewell worthy friend.
[Scudamore:] Nay look you, this same fashion does not please me,
You were not wont to make your visitation
So short and careless.
[Neville:] Tis your Jealousy
That makes you think it so [...] and so Good-morrow.

ww_a1d99a2e302999c6.text:
[Neville:] [...] Yet think on't, keep thy secret, and thy friend
Sure and entire [...].

ww_0c8fb7f90aa902f3.text: Nevill disguises himself as a parson to perform the double wedding ceremonies of the sisters Bellafront and Kate. This means that the marriages will be invalid and Nevill's friend Scudmore has a chance to win Bellafront, whom he loves.

ww_e0cc11b8e146026b.text:
[Count Frederick:] Pendant thou'lt make me dote upon my self.
[Pendant:] Narcissus by this hand, had far less cause.

ww_a2c8c5a7421000b6.text:
[Strange:]: For some say some men on the back of Law,
May ride and rule it like a patient Ass,
And with a Golden Bridle in the mouth,
Direct it unto any thing they please.
Others report, it is a Spider's web,
Made to entangle the poor helpless Flies,
While the great Spiders that did make it first,
And rule it, sit i'th midst secure and laugh [...].

ww_dab263235c799227.text: [Pendant:] [...] for profit, this Marriage (God speed it) marries you to it, and for pleasure, if I help you not to that as cheap as any man in England, call me Cut [...].

ww_28bcd2e0c72c44b5.text: [Sir Abraham:] Oh Sir, I was in love today, and could not eat, but here's one knows the case is alter'd, lend me but a Handkerchief to wipe my mouth, and I have done.

ww_6e305b78a62b964d.text:
[Castabella:] [...] be not displeas'd if on
The altar of his tomb I sacrifice
My tears.

ww_3ee86519fef80fbf.text:
[D'Amville:] Go, th' art the base corruption of my blood,
And like a tetter grow'st unto my flesh.

ww_d6f67b782909f387.text: [Sebastian:] [...] so you'll but put money i' my purse.

ww_b0b21f113fc7988b.text: [Sebastian:] [...] Th' hast trebles and basses enough, treble injury and base usage. But trebles and basses make poor music without means. Thou want'st means, dost?

ww_40a1dfdae82b58c4.text:
[Guido Count of Arsena:] Sancta Maria! What thinkst thou of this change?
A Player's passion I'll believe hereafter,
And in a Tragic Scene weep for olde Priam,
 When fell revenging Pyrrhus with supposed
And artificial wounds mangles his breast,
And think it a more worthy act to me,
Than trust a female mourning ore her love:
Naught that is done of woman shall me please,
Natures step-children rather her desire.

ww_65c5fceaf2998c98.text:
[Castabella:] O father, mercy is an attribute
As high as justice, an essential part
Of his unbound goodness, whose divine
Impression, form, and image man should bear.
And methinks man should love to imitate
His mercy, since the only countenance
Of justice were destruction, if the sweet
And loving favour of his mercy did
Not meditate between it and our weakness.

ww_ea99c4404667c0ab.text: [Cataplasma:] [...] What's here? A medlar with a plum tree gowing hard by it [...].

ww_abe4c347bce04d18.text: [Sebastian:] [...] But here's a moral. A pop'ring pear tree growing upon the bank of a river [...].

ww_9dcbc7f06b5591b7.text: [D'Amville:] Why doest thou stare upon me?

ww_14f97d5ed28307f6.text:
[Angus:] Now does he feel
His secret murders sticking on his hands.

ww_5dcab4d533187072.text:
[D'Amville:] [...] but now that I begin to feel
The loathsome horror of my sin [...].

ww_5525cb7b5d639101.text:
[D'Amville:] O were my body circumvolv'd
Within that cloud, that when the thunder tears
His passage open, it might scatter me
To nothing in the air!

ww_1a185149b887ddbb.text:
[Levidulcia:] [...] My strange affection to this man! 'Tis like
That natural sympathy which e'en among
The senseless creatures of the earth commands
A mutual inclination and consent.
For though it seems to be the free effect
Of mine own voluntary love, yet I
Can neither restrain it, nor give reason for 't.

ww_188967b6ae3bd42f.text: [Levidulcia:] [...] if they bid thee not welcome, they are very loggerheads.

ww_0bfefd4b1307c5b6.text: [Third Servant:] Why then take thy liquor. a health, Fresco! (kneels)

ww_7cc07a625ded3ae8.text:
[D'Amville:] [...] for the appetite
That steals her pleasures, draws the forces of
The body to an united strength and puts
'Em altogether into action,
Never fails of procreation.

ww_79e73b0711d9420f.text: [Second Servant:] Do you take that in snuff, sir?

ww_14fb035cea48fb63.text: [D'Amville:] I'll tell thee what sha't do: knock him over the pate with thy torch; I'll bear thee out in't.

ww_d718b134c90e1973.text:
[Levidulcia:] [...] Why sure their generation was asleep
When she begot those dormice, that she made
Them up so weakly and imperfectly.

ww_44f38b3c22da647f.text:
[Claridiana:] Slave, I will fight with thee at any odds,
Or name an instrument fit for destruction,
That e'er was made to make away a man,
I'll meet thee on the ridges of the Alps,
Or some inhospitable wilderness [...].

ww_7589fd1e5d190b51.text:
[Levidulcia:] [...] I could unbrace and entertain
The air to cool it.

ww_72147da23ba4751a.text: [Abigal:] [...] one that (it seem'd) <span class="quote">fear'd no colours [...].

ww_d0a00337de99eed8.text: [Roberto:] [...] And taste a homely banquet we entreate.

ww_f2817ce930cb87ce.text: [Anna:] [...] I was the Indian, yet you had the treasure.

ww_047fb70dc6809c79.text:
[D'Amville:] Dead be your tongues! Drop out
Mine eye-balls, and let envious Fortune play
At tennis with 'em. Have I liv'd to this?
Malicious Nature! Hadst thou born me blind,
Th'hadst yet been something favourable to me.
No breat? No motion? Prithee tell me, Heaven,
Hast shut thine eye to wink at murder, or
Hast put the sable garment on to mourn
At's death?
Not one poor spark in the whole spacious sky
Of all that endless number would vouchsafe
To shine? You viceroys to the king of Nature!
Whose constellations govern mortal births,
Where is that fatal planet rul'd at his
Nativity? That might ha' pleas'd to light
Him out, as well into th' world, unless
It be asham'd t' have been the instrument
Of such a good man's cursed destiny.

ww_c75a4dd3312799cb.text: [Don Sago:] [...] A hundred times in life a coward dies.

ww_13d35c6c450dc867.text:
[Don Sago:] [...] misers, that imprison'd gold
Within the harmless bowels of the earth.

ww_5bc4087fc1196013.text:
[D'Amville:] [...] That rather than ha' trod upon a worm
He would ha'shunn'd the way [...].

ww_65b15ddc160aa895.text:
[D'Amville:] That power of rule philosophers ascribe
To him they call the supreme of the stars,
Making their influences governors
Of sublunary creatures, when their selves
Are senseless of their operations [...].

ww_f795e2d015148a46.text: [Fresco:] [...] I bid him hang himself in his own garters.

ww_580285cd84b4b262.text:
[Charlemont:] [...] Dreams are but the rais'd
Impressions of premeditated things,
By serious apprehension left upon
Our minds, or else th' imaginary shapes
Of objects proper to th' complexion or
The disposition of our bodies.

ww_e10ef9b5f5754bd1.text:
[Clermont:] Twas but your fancie then awaking dreame:
For as in sleepe, which bindes both th' outward senses,
And the sense common to; th' imagining power
(Stird vp by formes hid in the memories store,
Or by the vapours of o'er-flowing humours
In bodies full and foule; and mixt vvith spirits,)
Faines many strange, miraculous images,
In which act, it so painfully applyes
It selfe to those formes, that the common sense
It actuates with his motion; and thereby
Those fictions true seeme, and haue reall act:
So, in the strength of our conceits, awake,
The cause alike, doth of like fictions make.

ww_5c04c6b005653902.text: [Hercules:] Behold, this monstrous rock thy death shall crown […].

ww_d27cbd2362897b13.text: [Melantius:] Why? wilt thou dote thyself out of thy life? Hence get thee to bed, have a careful looking to, and eat warm things and trouble not me: my head is full of thoughts more weighty than thy like of Death can be.

ww_af41ed7bae2a2ab5.text:
[Bosola:] [...] We are merely the Stars' tennis balls (struck, and bandied
Which way please them) [...].

ww_af30d16b702d0925.text: [Atlas:] [...] whom it hath pleased fortune to make her tennis ball of, and therefore subject to be struck by every fool into hasard.

ww_0e3988bb73241d4a.text:
[Ferdinand:] [...] or doth thy friendship play
In this antipathous extreme with mine [...].

ww_8876729c47ddeca4.text:
[Ferdinand:] [...] thy bosom binds some secret
Which do not trust me with [...].

ww_112ea362ee6737f6.text: Four Plays in One [Beaumont and Fletcher 1905 Glover edition volume 10, p. 38]" (William Peery. The Plays of Nathan Field: Edited from the Original Quartos with Introduction and Notes. Austin: The University of Texas Press, 1950. 244).

ww_7c6be9e3abb82dcc.text: [Gerrard:] My Lords, the Law is but the great mans mule; he rides on it [...]

ww_4062983cf42091eb.text: What averse Star rul'd my nativity?

ww_cbbeb2260e7c3d64.text:
[Helena:] [...] Was this wrinkled forehead
When 'twas at best, worth half so many lives?
Where is that beauty? lives it in this face
Which hath set two parts of the World at war,
Been ruin of the Asian Monarchy,
And almost this of Europe ? this the beauty
That launch'd a thousand ships from Aulis' gulf?

ww_5ce4db78e4150094.text:
[Chersogles:] Spreading his fearful ensigns in the air,
Like some prodigious comet, we may fear speedy revenge [...]

ww_8636b722a74ca4ed.text: This scene is very similar to Act 1, scene 2 in Nathan Field's A Woman is a Weather-Cock.

ww_af78259e84dc7aee.text:
Alas, poore Booke, hunt not thou after prayse,
Nor dare to stretch thy hand vnto the Bayes
Vpon a Poets head: let it suffice
To thee and me, the world doth vs despise.
For 'tis a mad World, and it turnes on hinges,
Whilst some a birding goe, and set their springes
For to catch Woodcocks. Others sting and bite
Like Wasps and Mastiffs, and doe take delight
To quarrell with their shaddowes, nay, themselues,
And their owne broode.

ww_7daccc4dc709b890.text:
[Aymour:] Flatters, detracts, impaires, yet put it by,
Lest thou dear Lord (Narcissus-like) should dote
Upon thyself, and die; and rob the world
Of nature's copy, that she works form by.

ww_2fe7b27125c9a884.text:
[Oriana:] Are all my hopes come to this? Is there no faith?
No troth? nor modesty in men?

ww_3a4d8d17f688ec42.text:
[Alexander:] No, no, no; I will not go down (makes himself unready) now I think on't.
[Widow:] Why, what do you mean, you will not be so uncivil to unbrace you here?
[Alexander:] By these Buckles I will, and what they will think on't [...].

ww_b30b2a8d282ff0f5.text: [...] there, and rose again in Burgoigne. But the greater miracle is behind (for thereby hangs a tale.) This man sued a divorce, and was separated from his wife [...].

ww_994ef297b3a834d0.text:
[Bubulcus:] O that I were a flea upon his lip,
There would I suck for ever, and not skip.

ww_dc5efc791d437593.text:
[Welborne:] They are well rewarded
That beggar themselves to make such cuckolds rich.
Thou viper, thankless viper; impudent bawd!
But since you are grow'n forgetful, I will help
Your memory, and tread thee into mortar:
 Not leave one bone unbroken.

ww_aa643a296777cf63.text: [Pynto:] Avant, I saw twelve dozen of Cuckolds in the middle region of the air, galloping on a black Jack, Eastward ho. [...] Now, now, now, my brains burn in Sulphur, and thus will I stalk about, and swim through a whole Element of dainty, neat, brisk, rich claret, canary, or maligo. Am not I Pynto, have not I hiren here? What art thou, a full moon, or a moon calf?

ww_8121bf4190a06f31.text: [Clown:] I confess it; but whether you haue serv'd him well, or no, there hangs a Tale. Stro. How doth thy noble Lady, faire Lauret [...].

ww_34c8aa16812bb7a4.text:
[Athenais:] If I could leave my understanding to you,
It were superfluous to make division
Of whatsoever else I can bequeath you,
But to avoid contention, I allot
An equal portion of my possessions
To you my sons: but unto thee my daughter,
My joy, my darling (pardon me though I
Repeat his words) if my prophetic soul
Ready to take her flight, can truely guess at
Thy future fate, I leave the strange assurance
Of the greatness thou art born to, unto which
Thy brothers shall be proud to pay their service.

ww_fac3e3b98eda4be1.text:
[Athenais:] [...] shall I,
His vassal from obscurity rais'd by him
To this so eminent light, presume to appoint him
To do, or not to do this, or that: when wives
Are well aocommodated by their husbands
With all things both for use, and ornament,
Let them fix there, and never dare to question
Their wills or actions.

ww_0a9c047f70f05ac7.text:
[Annabella:] [...] Would thou hadst been lesse subject to those Stars
That luckless reign'd at my Nativity [...].

ww_369f81218a80cc3c.text:
[D'Avolos:] A shrewd ominous token;
I like not that neither.
[Duke:] Again! What is't you like not?

ww_f07ac9df61678d5c.text:
[Landrey:] Most true, you wept.
[Queen:] As a good Actor in a play would do,
Whose fancy works (as if he waking dreamt)
Too strongly on the Object that it copes with,
Shaping realities from mockeries;
And so the queen did weep. [...]
By this good night
I think I could become the Stage as well
As any she that sels her breath in publique.

ww_c6cf4e2e7927f350.text:
[Crotilda as the eunuch Castrato:] Is't even so, work and about my brain,
I'm lost for ever if not close again.

ww_f9330e328f5bcfea.text: [Clotair:] I'll take thy word, Eunuch, for the Kingdom's wealth.

ww_88f2bbfdc34e987a.text:
[Old Brissac:] Pray let me see the Ring; yes it was hers,
And she would say she'd never part with it
But when she meant to wed; if y'have married her,
Or have her promise riveted to yours,
Tell me but where she is, I'll be content,
For I in losing her have lost my joy.
[Charles Brissac:] Is she not then within?
[Old Brissac:] Yes too much; oh no
The house contains her not, she is not here,
Nor is for ought I know at all.
[Clovis the Prince:] O my prophetic soul, then 'tis no idle fear.

ww_58f781e2d257b94c.text:
[Clotair:] Whom d'ye hold discourse with, the air?
Bethink yourself, this is no time to dally.

ww_83110dc1fd25afd7.text:
[Eunuch:] [...] If (in her proud desire) I do prevent
Her lust this second time, before the third
She may repent and save her loathed soul,
Which my revenge would damn; yet were she crossed,
Her lust being now at full flood in her,
And no way left to quench her burning flame,
Her drier bones would make a bonfire,
Fit for the Devill to warm his hands by [...].

ww_3ef157950bb184cd.text:
[Clovis:] I am no spirit; tast my active pulse,
And you shall find it makes such harmony
As youth and health enjoy.

ww_84ac44b73b0bbac5.text: We desire forbidden things, and that is the perversenesse of your flesh, that will not be brideled with no lawful bounds, and wee see by experience that many men that have beautiful wives neglect their own better, and pray upon others more deformed. For Virtue as it never will be moved, though lewdness court it in the shape of heaven; So Lust, though to a radiant Angel linked, will sort itself in a terrestrial bed, and prey on garbage.

ww_1a3466a7a469a574.text:
[...] Nay, I have done; beware of jealousy;
 I would not have you nourish jealous thoughts [...].

ww_ef33f770d455546b.text:
[Crotilda as the eunuch Castrato:] King, thou hadst better far have strook thy Father,
Dig'd up his bones and plaid at logats with them.

ww_b76fa82ae6db4f8a.text:
[Clovis:] [...] Though she has broke her faith to me, to you
Against her reputation she'll be true [...].

ww_2c7593c39d035309.text:
[Crotilda as the eunuch Castrato:] 'Tis true, I tell your Oracle;
There's not an hour's life between ye both;
 The poison's sure, I did prepare it for ye,
And have my self taken an Antidote [...].

ww_31a5d8733533b712.text:
[Clovis:] [...] The drowsy Poppy, cold Mandragora,
Or all the sleepy syrups of the world [...].

ww_d3384d1801d92ace.text:
[Clotair:] The motions of the Sphæres move in that tongue.
Turn all your sables to the Tyrian dye,
Your dirges into sprightful wedding airs.

ww_2f374130bacf29a1.text:
[Second Soldier:] [...] The Monsieur, like the God of war, bestrides
A bounding Courser, who is therefore proud
To be so back'd, as knowing whom he bears:
So Centaur-like he's anchor'd to his seat,
As he had twind with the proud steed he rides on;
He grows unto his saddle all one piece,
And that unto his Horse; Sits like a Perseus on his Pegasus,
Stable and fleet.

ww_91ad182437d2217a.text:
[Queen:] What French Neronian spirit have we here?
Insolent boy, wilt thou turn Parricide?

ww_6e03506358e0e8c9.text: [Clovis:] I'll tear him all to pieces then [...].

ww_784345580b7f2614.text:
[Clotair:] [...] lock up in me
The Organs of remorse, all faculties
That write me man, or mankind; create
A spirit of horror in me, apt me to look
Upon such deeds nature would tremble at,
And the discreet composure of the world
Melt and dissolve to nothing, whilst I unmov'd
Smile at the alteration [...]

ww_1c5c60306848e4d1.text:
[Clothair:] [...] kiss me sweet,
[Kisses her.]
There's no deceit lies here [...].

ww_7202a693105de657.text:
[Queen:] [...] But tell me Landrey, how did I play the mother;
Did not I seem a Niobe in passion,
A deluge of salt tears?

ww_f01dd821f9c6fe34.text:
[Clovis:] [...] Oh King,
For I am swift as thought that executes.

ww_9ff0e88db317fcb5.text:
[Clothair:] [...] It is not murder, tender-hearted fool
Which thou commitst, rather a sacrifice [...].

ww_8b83f6fcc923e0d6.text:
[Queen:] I grant th'as great a Basilisk as he,
As thou art merely man; but as thy King
Divinity doth prop him, he stands firm
That builds on that foundation

ww_dd1513adb5374d55.text:
[Queen:] [...] sure thou hast bought
A pair of cast lips of the chaste Diana's [...].

ww_8ea0e1782e72b510.text:
[Clotair:] [...] my passions but like lightning
Flash and away, dead e'er we say it is.

ww_5b2a49851e9717b9.text:
[Aphelia:] I'll force a gentler nature in the steel,
And with my rainy eyes weep out their heat;
Which as it dies should hiss it self to scorn [...].

ww_72ccdeccae445d5a.text: [Clotair:] No more of that, it tends to madness [...].

ww_49344abb6e143df2.text:
[Landrey:] Poor unfed sides that pass along the street,
I now am sensible of what ye want [...].

ww_5742934297a1f4dd.text:
[Queen:] Within the clothed circle of mine eyes,
Anchor thy fingers; alas, thy nails are par'd.

ww_7ff8ee624afeb233.text: [Queen:] Let thy hand sacrifice not butcher him.

ww_dcd4681515288ad0.text:
[Charles Brissac:] My noble Father -
[Old Brissac:] Tut, tut, tut! Noble me [no] nobles, nor Father me No Fathers.

ww_d163917e509be1a8.text:
[Queen:] [...] Thy brother's ghost, young Clovis Ghost in arms
Has thrice appear'd to me this dismal night.

ww_2ff5cdc06325f7d4.text:
[Clotair:] My brother's spirit in arms, I swear it came forth here
Out of my Mothers Chamber as I knockt.

ww_a80087091ee95a85.text:
[Crotilda as the eunuch Castrato:] Was it in Armour, said you?
[Clotair:] Yes in that Armor he was us'd to wear
When we have run at tilt.

ww_2eff896b8bb6a3bf.text: [Queen:] [...] Appearing in his Brother's warlike form [...].

ww_abc6fb1cc681fb66.text:
[Dumaine:] We are not safe Lamot; this bawdie peace
Begets a war within me; our swords worn
For Ornament, not use; the Drum & Trumpet
Sing drunken Carrols, and the Canon speaks
Health, not confusion [...].

ww_c1cf9d6bc33eea80.text:
[Dumaine:] Hark, the thunder of the world, how out of tune.
This peace corrupting all things makes them speak.
What means this most adulterate noise?
[Lamot:] Why, are you ignorant?
This is a night of jubilee, and the King
Solemnly feasts for his war's happy success.

ww_f6940b06098f7cd0.text:
[Clovis:] What is it, Eunuch? [...] Though death stood gaping wide to swallow me,
I wold not shrink nor fear.

ww_1dd27972253ebc97.text:
[Clotair:] What art thou that usurp'st this dead of night,
 In metal like the age? why art thou sent
To cast a horror on me?

ww_845de84107df1153.text:
[Clovis:] Hold, hold my heart - can I endure this -
Unhand me, Charles, and render me myself,
Lest I forget myself on thee.

ww_b8f647514479fad2.text:
[Clotair:] [...] let her sin
Be punish'd from above; I'll wait heaven's leisure.

ww_4ac1b9e168eb72cd.text: [Younger Pallatine:] Men o' the puissant Pike, follow the lights.

ww_6ecd6e98957a9e44.text:
[Hannibal:] Like a perpetual comet to fright Rome
With his prodigious light.

ww_e9015346c8c0ea29.text:
[Aurelio:] [...] Oh that I were a vail upon that face,
To hide it from the world; methinks I could
Envie the very Sun, for gazing on you!

ww_5a285fb67d61c0ec.text:
Like Jove and Juno in a nuptial knot,
We'll knit the bands of Hymen, and outshine
The glorious Tapers of the golden Sun,
Whirl through the stately streets of spacious Rome
Like glistring Phaeton in an Orient chair.

ww_8c22b084ec9df6f2.text:
And nought so rich on either rock or shelf,
But, if unknown, lies useless to it self.
Therefore who thus doth make their secrets known,
Doth profit others, and not hurt his own.

ww_88b0da8573bfcf23.text:
[Octavio:] My only child: I murmur'd against heaven
Because I had no more; but now I find
This one too many.

ww_935f51df94080f65.text: [Nassuras:] Rare Rogue in Buckram, let me bite thee.

ww_0855d22192e195ae.text:
[Cater:] Sure they are asleep, perhaps
The Slave being overleaven'd with his favour
Hath made himself stark drunk; we shall disturb
Our Lady and her Daughter, I much wonder
Mistris Nugella comes not to the door.

ww_4fd4d1baf9ae5108.text:
Some women are in Churches Saints or more,
Angels abroad, at home too like the Devil,
At windows Syrens, Parrots at the door;
And in their gardens Goats, or more uncivil:
And Tradesmen that were match till they have much,
In deadly danger are to meet with such.

ww_54d4ed8880623baa.text: the mad boys that trail the puissant pike

ww_2e91c20e5f56ecf3.text:
[Gaselles:] [...] his buxom wife; who though she be not clad in Persian Silks, or costly Tyrian Purples,
has a clean skin, soft thighs, and wholesome corps,
fit for the trailer of the puissant Pike,
to solace in delight with.

ww_f57075216fd4f1b6.text: Stand off, gentlemen, - let me see - which? Hum! this? - no; th'other! Hum! send for a lion and turn him loose; he won't hurt the true prince.

ww_fb65ad93264a0ff0.text: [Common-curse:] Rare rogue in Buckram - thou shalt got out a wit, and vie with Martin Parker, or John Tailor.

ww_c7f6e24c9df42311.text:
[Almanzor:] Why then we shall do all our work at once; I hate delays, let Fortune give me my Answer quickly, whether a Monarch or a Slave; - If my Stars have in this Fate this Crown, This day 'tis (aside) mine; if not, there's a hope lost.
[Clytus:] If you could produce the person of our King, my prophetick soul tells me the day were ours; such a signal Victory would make all their hearts turn Coward; the justice and vengeance they must expect from his injuries would wound farther and deeper than either Sword or Spear.

ww_59d438f20a50be60.text:
[Rifaloro:] The scurvy Poet, giving each a Sonnet ,
Leaves only me without - But, by the faith
Of a Mahumetan, since thus he hath
Provok'd me to't, upon his skirts I'll sit:
Damme all his Matter, 'cause in Verse 'tis writ:
And, in defiance of the Triple Three,
Promote a Law, importing, that, to bee,
Or not to be, a Poet; shall suffice

ww_cdb8c5ac9e54fe9e.text:
[Ulysses:] Thus we see ended all these fatal Broils,
The Plague of War, and Ten Years constant Toils -
First lend each noble Arm to lift in State,
This gallant Corps, and mourn Achilles Fate;
Then, like a Soldier, bear him to the Fleet,
Losing no time to court inconstant Gales,
But with glad Shouts fill all our empty Sails,
Turning our Joyful Eyes upon the Plain,
Where the sad Troy in Ashes does remain.

ww_bcc835a51219d969.text:

Fiends tear him; Blasted be the Arm that strook,
The Tongue that order'd; - Onely She be spar'd
That hindred not the Deed. O, where was then
The Power that guards the Sacred Lives of Kings?
Why slept the Lightning and the Thunder-bolts,
Or bent their idle rage on Fields and Trees,
When Vengeance call'd 'em here?

ww_21fcbfcb83952d6b.text:
[Melanax:] I told thee true:
But Lucifer, as he who foremost fell,
So now lies lowest in th'Abyss of Hell.
Chain'd till the dreadful Doom, in place of whom
Sits Beelzebub, Vicegerent of the damn'd,
Who listning downward hears his roaring Lord,
And executes his purpose, but no more
The morning creeps behind yon Eastern hill,
And now the Guard is mine, to drive the Elves
And foolish Fairies from their Moon-light Play,
And lash the Laggers from the sight of day.
(Descends.)

ww_66b6614569557cd9.text: Vickers nonpubl CiceroDolman "if my sense shall be extinct, and my death resemble sleep, which often without any trouble of dreams, doth bring a man most quiet rest, (O Lorde) what pleasure shall death be to me!" (1.41.97; Sig. G6r). If it be true, Socrates continues, "that death is a departure into these regions, which all they inhabite, that are departed out of this life", then "this ought to seem a sweet pilgrimage" (1.41.98; Sig. G6r-v). Cicero reiterated these sentiments, wishing “that either men would hereafter desire death, ot at the least wise, cease to fear it. For if at the last day of our life, our souls die not, but only change their place, what ought we more to wish? But if death do utterly destroy us, what can be better, than in the rage of great storms, sweetly to slumber? and after that a man hath nodded out of this life, to sleep everlastingly.(1.49.117; Sig. H8r) The parallels [...] link up with Hamlet's later metaphor of death as "The undiscover'd country, from whose bourn / No traveller returns".

ww_07f209ee763b5bfc.text: [Philautes to Euphues his son]: At thy comming into England, be not too inquisitive of news, neither curious in matters of State, in assemblies ask no questions, either concerning manners or me. Be not lavish of thy tongue, either in causes of weight, least thou shew thy self an espy-all, or in wanton talk, least thou prove thy self a fool. It is the Nature of that country to sift strangers, every one that shaketh thee by the hand is not joined to thee in heart. They think Italians Wanton, & Grecians subtile, they will trust neither, they are so incredulous, but undermine both, they are so wise. Be not querulous for every light occasion, they are impatient in their anger of any equal, ready to revenge an iniury, but never want to proffer any: they never fight without provoking, and once provoked, they never cease. Beware thou fal not into the snares of love, the women there are wise, the men crafty: they will gather love by thy looks, and pick thy mind out of thy hands. It shall be there better to hear what they say, then to speak what thou thinkest: They have long ears and short tongues, quick to hear, and slow to utter: broad eyes and light fingers, ready to espy and apt to strike.

[Philotimus:] Nay, rather he that loves suffers, and she works.
[Aurelia:] But hath not he free choice, to love or not to love?
[Philotimus:] He hath.
[Aurelia:] Then he kills himself that loves.
[Philotimus:] The woman kills not because she is loved, but because she loves not again. For whosoever may save, and will not, killeth.

During the rancour of my wicked mind,
And melting all in thoughts of sweet remorse,
How wise and gracious is this Persian king,

How honourable and magnanimious?

ww_fcb0bcde50ac3d87.text: But least I might seem with these night crows, Nimis curious in aliena republica. I'll turn back to my first text, of studies of delight; and talk a little in friendship with a few of our trivial translators. It is a common practise now a days amongst a sort of shifting companions, that run through every art and thrive by none, to leave the trade of Noverint whereto they were born, and busy themselves with the endeavors of Art, that could scarcely latinise their neck-verse if they should have need; yet English Seneca read by candlelight yields many good sentences, as Blood is a beggar, and so forth: and if you intreat him fair in a frosty morning, he will afford you whole Hamlets, I should say handfuls of tragical speeches.

Scudamour's "dram of hony" in a similarly fluid metaphor (IV.x.I.I-5): True he it said, what euer man it sayd, That loue with gall and hony doth abound, But if the one be with the other wayd, For euery dram of hony therein found, A pound of gall doth ouer it redound. 
In suggesting "o'er-redound" as an emendation for [of a doubt] in Q2 I recall Milton's use of the word with a similar connotation (P.L. VII.56-59): But the evil soon Driv'n back redounded as a flood on those From whom it sprung, impossible to mix With Blessedness

For when they once to perfect strength do grow,
Strong wars they make, and cruel battry bend
Gainst fort of Reason, it to overthrow.

ww_a517c08e711d74a2.text:
[Richard:] Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast,
But whiles he thought to steal the single ten,
The King was slyly fingered from the deck.

ww_87888a954cfda24f.text:
[King Henry:] Well, for this night we will repose us here.
Tomorrow toward London back again,
To look into this business thoroughly,
And call these foul offenders to their answers,
And poise the cause in Justice' equal scales,
Whose beam stands sure, whose rightful cause
prevails.

ww_b7671b939d5b0fbb.text: [Herner:] Masters, I am come hither, as it were, upon my man’s instigation, to prove him a knave and myself an honest man; and touching the Duke of York, I will take my death I never meant him any ill, nor the King, nor the Queen. - And therefore, Peter, have at thee with a downright blow!

ww_4715eb05fc789445.text:
[Clifford:] Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone.
This is the hand that stabbed thy father York,
And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland,
And here's the heart that triumphs in their death
And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother
To execute the like upon thyself.
And so, have at thee!

ww_2edab3526365daad.text:
[Lucy:] Is Talbot slain, the Frenchmen's only scourge,
Your kingdom's terror and black Nemesis?

ww_39f67adef619a39f.text:
[Clarence:] To keep that oath were more impiety
Than Jephthah when he sacrificed his daughter.

ww_a87dd238d00d444f.text: [Enter Segasto running and Amadine after him, <span class="quote">being pursued with a bear.]<span>

ww_eabeb7297fd02072.text:
[Bolingbroke:] [...] Deep night, dark night, the silent of the night,
The time of night when Troy was set on fire,
The time when screech owls cry and bandogs howl,
And spirits walk, and ghosts break up their graves -
That time best fits the work we have in hand.

ww_2329877f08132751.text: [...] walking spirits which have been so much talked of in time of popery, and were taken for the souls of them which were dead [...] whether the souls of men departed walk after death and appear unto men, exhorting them unto this or that.

ww_cc19d0da24059d8e.text:
[Richard:] Fie! Charity, for shame! Speak not in spite,
For you shall sup with Jesu Christ tonight

ww_2dc9368a10a0e492.text:
[Giordano:] Why do you stand bare-headed? You do yourself wrong.
[Edward:] Pardon me, good sir, I do it for my ease.
[Giordano:] I pray you be covered, you are too ceremonious.
[Edward:] I am so well, that me thinks I am in heaven.
[Giordano:] If you love me, put on your hat.
[Edward:] I will do it to obey you, not for any leisure that I take in.

ww_ae9cb979f732b094.text: [Anselmo:] [...] Whether report gilded a worthlesse Trunk [...].

ww_361984a87f87dabc.text: Then, if we had seen a man go wallowing in the streets, or line sleeping under the board, we would have spat at him as a toad, and called him [a] foul drunken swine [...].

ww_50d17a1fdc4fa606.text:
[Demetrius:] [...] Though Bassianus be the Emperor’s brother,
Better than he have worn Vulcan's badge.

ww_d881604f654196c6.text: [Bianca:] What, master, read you? First resolve me that.

ww_27042e402aa3b5c4.text: Thus walks he up and down in his Majesty, taking a yard of ground at every step, and stamps on he earth so terribly, as if he meant to knock up spirits, when (foul drunken bezzle) if an Englishman set his little finger to him, he falls like a hogs-trough that is set on one end.

ww_80c53ef755113cac.text: [Grumio:] Out of their saddles into the dirt, <span class="quote">and thereby hangs a tale.

ww_29d101ca9b9a0b61.text: Clim of the Clough [the devil] thou that usest to drink nothing but scalding lead and sulphur in hell, thou art not so greedy of thy night gear. O, but thou hast a foul swallow, if it come once to carousing of human blood; but that's but seldom [...] otherwise thou art tide at rack and manger, and drinkest nothing but the Aqua vitae of vengeance all thy life time [...].

ww_ed0731546c16f09e.text:
Sloth and sluggish security [...].

[...] neglect [...] dallying [...] indignities [...] love-dream [...].

ww_bcc4b76a020e8511.text: I will not forget the old wives logick, when Adam delved and Eve spanne, who was then a Gentleman?

ww_0a0243bf95a1743f.text: [Duke:] [...] Go, some of you, knock at the abbey gate [...].

ww_df217d2caab3c319.text:
[Edward:] I cannot brook these haughty menaces […]

[Edward:] Cease brother, for I cannot brook these words […]

[Gaveston:] My Lord I cannot brook these iniuries.

ww_2132d10675497d48.text: A mighty deformer of men's manners and features, is this unnecessary vice of all other. Let him be indued with never so many virtues, and have as much goodly proportion and favour as nature can bestow upon a man; yet if he be thirsty after his own destruction, and hath no joy nor comfort, but when he is drowning his soul in a gallon pot, that one beastly imperfection will utterly obscure all that is commendable in him; and all his good qualities sink like lead down to the bottom of his carousing cups, where they will lie, like lees and dregs, dead and unregarded of any man.

ww_e1e972859949a549.text: For besides, nature hath left him a flaberkin face, like one of the four winds, and cheeks that sag like a woman's dugs over his chin-bone, his apparel is so put up with bladders of Taffeta, and his back like beef stuffed with Parsley, so drawn out with Ribands and deuces, and blistered with light sarcenet bastings, that you would think him [a Dane] nothing but a swarm of Butterflies, if you saw him a far off.

ww_f698815b34a31d14.text: The Danes are bursten-bellied sots, that are to be confuted with nothing but Tankards or quart-pots, and Ovid might as well have read his verses to the Geese that understood him not, as a man talk reason to them that have no ears but their mouths nor sense but of that which they swallow down their throats. God so love me, as I love the quick-witted Italians, and therefore love them more, because they mortally detest this surley swinish Generation.

ww_f750f294ab2da720.text: Men when they are idle, and know not what to do, saith one let us go to the Steelyard and drink Rhenish wine. Nay, if a man knew where a good whorehouse were saith another, it were somwhat like. Nay saith the third, let us go to a dicing-house or a bowling alley, and there we shall have some sport for our money.

ww_b25daebf8629c967.text: Besides, my vagrant Reveller haunts Plays, & sharpens his wits with frequenting the company of Poets; he emboldens his blushing face by courting fair women on the sudden, and look into all Estates, by conversing with them in public places. Now tell me whether of these two, the heavy-headed gluttonous house dove, or this lively wanton young Gallant, is likely to prove the wiser man, and better member in the Common-wealth.

ww_87803ecab661976f.text: Sloth in Nobility, Courtiers, Scholars, or any men is the chiefest cause that brings them in contempt. For as industry and unfatigable toil raiseth mean persons from obscure houses to high thrones of authority: so Sloth and sluggish security causeth proud Lords to tumble from the towers of their starry descents, and be trodden underfoot of every inferior Bosnian. […] The only enemy to Sloth is contention and emulation; as propose one man to myself, that is the only mirror of our Age, and strive to out-go him in virtue.

ww_52a8f0cf52e21b23.text: That is the course he that will be popular must take, which if he neglect, and sit dallying at home, nor will be awaked by any indignities out of his love-dream, but suffer every upstart groom to defy him, set him at naught, and shake him by the beard unrevenged, let him straight take orders and be a Churchman, and then his patience may pass for a virtue, but otherwise he shall be suspected of cowardice, and not car'd for of any.

ww_dea47f1bdf73667b.text:
[Edward:] [...] Gallop apace, bright Phoebus, through the sky,
And, dusky Night, in rusty iron car [...].

ww_52ddee34625bb8a9.text:
[Saturninus:] [...] My lords, you know, as know the mightful gods,
However these disturbers of our peace
Buzz in the people's ears, there naught hath passed
But even with law against the willful sons
Of old Andronicus.

ww_6a8dfb000c0563f3.text:
[Younger Mortimer:] [...] Farewell, fair queen. Weep not for Mortimer,
That scorns the world, and, as a traveller,
Goes to discover countries yet unknown.

ww_a0693828f45a0318.text:
[Young Lucius:] Grandsire, 'tis Ovid's Metamorphosis.
 My mother gave it me.

ww_ac413c960b3f46ba.text:
[King Richard:] For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground
And tell sad stories of the death of kings -
How some have been deposed, some slain in war […].

ww_8207568848475533.text:
[King Richard:] Let me unkiss the oath twixt thee and me;
And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made. -
Part us, Northumberland […].

ww_dba7eca465e8143a.text:
[York:] […] Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed,
Which his aspiring rider seemed to know […].

ww_f101e6ad7939110d.text:
[Ghosts of Princes:] Sleep, Richmond, sleep in peace and wake in joy.
Good angels guard thee from the boar's annoy.

ww_f50ba3ce342f7b70.text:
[Richard:] Go, gentlemen, every man unto his charge.
Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls.
Conscience is but a word that cowards use,
Devised at first to keep the strong in awe.

ww_99f59b7622b7f2e0.text: [Gaunt:] Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour.

ww_c4f47388a55f154b.text:
[Richard:] Thou sing’st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel.
Go, by this token. Rise, and lend thine ear.
There is no more but so. Say it is done,
And I will love thee and prefer thee for it.

ww_3c24c61bfe578994.text: [Buckingham:] My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.

ww_99f2e8ee0e886305.text: To the most honoured and virtuous, beautified lady, the lady Elizabeth Carey

ww_aa99fe97b00483e9.text:
[Richard:] He was the right, and so indeed it is.
Tell the clock there. Give me a calendar.
Who saw the sun today?
 [Ratcliffe:] Not I, my lord.

ww_e183d4f00814614b.text:
[Richmond:] The father rashly slaughtered his own son;
The son, compelled, been butcher to the sire.

ww_8a7f68cac7685251.text:
[Richard:] Give me another horse! Bind up my wounds!
Have mercy, Jesu! - Soft, I did but dream.
O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!

ww_424253a2963de103.text:
[Duchess:] Dead life, blind sight, poor mortal living ghost,
Woe’s scene, world’s shame, grave’s due by life usurped,
Brief abstract and record of tedious days,
 Rest thy unrest on England’s lawful earth,
Unlawfully made drunk with innocent blood.

ww_51c5ddb7baff7fe2.text:
I have a fine bow, and an ivory arrow:
And if thou miss, yet meat thou shalt lack,
I'll hang a bag and bottle at thy back.

Wilt thou set springs in a frosty Night,
To catch the long-billed Woodcock and the Snipe?
(By the bright glimmering of the Starry light)
The Partridge, Phaesant, or the greedy Crype?

ww_c379c9a74a9898d2.text: [...] because they fear not death, they shold fear something after death [...].

ww_3abc480d4071fad6.text:
For princes are the glass, the school, the book,
Where subjects' eyes do learn, do read, do look.

ww_cf904c000bc2e695.text: If of a number of shreds of his sentences he can shape an oration, from all the world he carries it away, although in truth it be no more than a fool's coat of many colours.

ww_06b1a59be68c2615.text: [Mercutio:] For this driveling love is like a great natural that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.

ww_60259cd3a1ff2259.text:
[Juliet:] How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
And the place death, considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

ww_cd801832b2f51499.text:
[Nurse:] There's no trust
No faith, no honesty in men.

ww_69f138786882781e.text:
[Mowbray:] [...] And now my tongue's use is to me no more
Than an unstringèd viol or a harp, up
Or, being open, put into his hands
That knows no touch to tune the harmony.

ww_77e194482ee6f799.text:
[Richard:] Must I do so? And must I ravel out
My weaved-up follies?

ww_c50a1a69817880e1.text: [Bolingbroke:] Go, some of you, and fetch a looking-glass.

ww_a17192d6d4852db1.text:
[Tybalt:] What, drawn and talk of peace? I hate the word
As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.
Have at thee, coward!

[Romeo:] Wilt thou provoke me? Then have at thee, boy!

ww_4cd60c9d958685b4.text: [Nurse:] [...] if you should lead her into a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say.

ww_f5a7054c0011149b.text:
[Romeo:] See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
O, that I were a glove upon that hand,
 That I might touch that cheek!

ww_2f8ef1847c5631ab.text:
[Nurse:] Even or odd, of all days in the year
 Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen. [...]
And she was weaned (I never shall forget it)
Of all the days of the year, upon that day.

ww_3224a831a8c5362a.text:
[Gardener:] Poor queen, so that thy state might be no worse,
I would my skill were subject to thy curse.
Here did she fall a tear. Here in this place
I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace.

ww_f8461dc2b3b1cf1c.text: [First Watch:] Go, some of you; whoe'er you find, attach.

ww_05c97b1e129c7589.text: [Bolingbroke:] Go, some of you, convey him to the Tower.

ww_67e00092d3b66d63.text:
[Mercutio:] [...] Now will he sit under a medlar tree
And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit
As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.

ww_ca8a11047cce0eab.text:
[Mercutio:] [...] O Romeo, that she were, O, that she were
An open-arse, thou a pop'rin pear.

ww_c18a99ec668d444c.text:
[Oberon:] [...] So shall all the couples three
Ever true in loving be,
And the blots of Nature's hand
Shall not in their issue stand.

ww_09abcacdcaba6d61.text: [Lady Capulet:] Ay, sir, but she will none, she gives you thanks.

ww_322c35e8aee9aaf6.text:
[Lysander:] [...] I have a widow aunt, a dowager
Of great revenue, and she hath no child.
From Athens is her house remote seven leagues,
And she respects me as her only son.
There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee;
And to that place the sharp Athenian law
Cannot pursue us.

ww_f92d168e5da3d9b5.text:
[Juliet:] Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
Ere one can say "It lightens."

ww_a9a69f25c6693882.text:
[Benvolio:] He swung about his head, and cut the winds,
Who, nothing hurt withal, hiss'd him in scorn.

ww_a46c66fb439682d1.text:
[Capulet:] Wife, we scarce thought us blessed
That God had lent us but this only child,
But now I see this one is one too much,
And that we have a curse in having her.

ww_1d3ab7563eee2e3d.text:
[Oberon:] [...] And this ditty, after me
Sing and dance it trippingly.

ww_c8d4464eb5cf9a20.text:
[Friar:] And nought so rich on either rock or shelf,
But, if unknown, lies uselesse to it self.
Therefore who thus doth make their secrets known,
Doth profit others, and not hurt his own.

ww_421503bb9686fe52.text:
[Prince:] For never was a story of more woe
Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.

ww_0252fba9d4255764.text:
[York:] I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs
And labored all I could to do him right.
But in this kind to come, in braving arms,
Be his own carver and cut out his way
To find out right with wrong, it may not be.

ww_c9253afee2f20544.text:
[Juliet:] O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris,
From off the battlements of any tower,
Or walk in thievish ways, or bid me lurk
Where serpents are. Chain me with roaring bears,
Or hide me nightly in a charnel house,
/ O’ercovered quite with dead men’s rattling bones,
With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls.

ww_12ad2ff19d7cc554.text:
[Prologue:] [...] From forth the fatal loins of these two foes
A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life;
Whose misadventured piteous overthrows
Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.

ww_0a524ce8d92f2012.text:
But if these eyes of yours, (load-stars of Love,
Showing the World's great dance to your mind's eye!)
Cannot with all their demonstrations move
Kind apprehension in your fantasy,
Of dancing's virtue, and nobility:
How can my barbarous tongue win you there to
Which Heau'n and Earth's fair speech could never do?

ww_1ad44a54f22762c5.text:
[King:] Berowne is like an envious sneaping frost
That bites the firstborn infants of the spring.

ww_a803ddc7a8ab3547.text: Let us therefore pray that we be not miscarried by the deceits of the wicked pilot Satan, whose directions are merely indirect, and whose sails are deceitful, being glorious to the eye; and the bark wherein he carrieth his unhappy passengers seemeth to be a most secure cradle, gliding on without tempest or wave, until it come to the end of their race, where, alas! they fall into the gulf of perpetual perdition. Such a master is he, and such mariners are his false prophets, that they delight flesh and blood, and all their course seemeth sweet, but short: and sour merchandise shall they have, that pass in the pinnace of his poisoned errors.

ww_fa7276c3549e3d17.text:
[Armado:] Call’st thou my love "hobby-horse"?
[Boy:] No, master. The hobby-horse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney.

ww_915a189dcca54cf4.text:
[Pandulph:] The better act of purposes mistook
Is to mistake again; though indirect,
Yet indirection thereby grows direct,
And falsehood falsehood cures, as fire cools fire
Within the scorchèd veins of one new-burned.

ww_3cf6af4261079896.text:
[Catechysius the Hermit:] Now all is but the action of the Mind,
That rectifi'd, the rest is all but wind.

ww_8b2c57f28da8d24f.text:
[Bastard:] By heaven, these scroyles of Angiers flout you, kings,
And stand securely on their battlements
As in a theater, whence they gape and point
At your industrious scenes and acts of death.
Your royal presences, be ruled by me:
Do like the mutines of Jerusalem,
Be friends awhile, and both conjointly bend
Your sharpest deeds of malice on this town.

ww_ad08d1db588775f5.text:
[Portia:] [...] [I'll] prove the prettier fellow of the two,
And wear my dagger with the braver grace,
And speak between the change of man and boy
With a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps
Into a manly stride, and speak of frays
Like a fine bragging youth, and tell quaint lies
How honorable ladies sought my love,
Which I denying, they fell sick and died -
I could not do withal! - then I'll repent,
And wish, for all that, that I had not killed them.
And twenty of these puny lies I'll tell,
That men shall swear I have discontinued school
Above a twelvemonth.

ww_595960272731daaf.text: [Berowne:] [...] Well, I do nothing in the world but lie, and lie in my throat.

ww_313fd08e882fd567.text: [King:] [...] But to the place where. It standeth north-north-east and by east from the west corner of thy curious-knotted garden. There did I see that low-spirited swain, that base minnow of thy mirth [...].

ww_4b50a70f0ef69f49.text:
[King Philip:] [...] Our cannons' malice vainly shall be spent
Against th'invulnerable clouds of heaven.

ww_b7875021b58fa2b0.text:
[Berowne:] But love, first learnèd in a lady’s eyes,
Lives not alone immurèd in the brain,
But with the motion of all elements
Courses as swift as thought in every power,
And gives to every power a double power,
Above their functions and their offices.

ww_70cb970cc220a86b.text:
[Pembroke:] Indeed, we heard how near his death he was
Before the child himself felt he was sick.
This must be answered either here or hence.

ww_08066d10869afe39.text: The proper end of conscience is, to determin of things done. And by this one thing, conscience is distinguished from all other gifts of the mind as intelligence opinion, science faith, prudence. Intelligence simply conceives a thing to be or not to be: science judgeth it to be certain and sure: faith is a persuasion, whereby we believe things that are not [...].

ww_4a8c14879536f30d.text: [Falstaff:] Now, my masters, happy man be his dole, say I. Every man to his business.

ww_df51b050848e8f3e.text: [Shallow:] Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old and of the peace, if I see a sword out, my finger itches to make one.

ww_330a8ce9127ffddf.text: [Hostess Quickly:] No, thou arrant knave. I would to God that I might die, that I might have thee hanged. Thou hast drawn my shoulder out of joint.

ww_6dac0d9b4ca94d1f.text: [Falstaff:] What, upon compulsion? Zounds, an I were at the strappado or all the racks in the world, I would not tell you on compulsion. Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plentiful as blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon compulsion, I.

ww_4262277efbdca529.text: [Falstaff:] Will you tell me, Master Shallow, how to choose a man? Care I for the limb, the thews, the stature, bulk, and big assemblance of a man! Give me the spirit, Master Shallow.

ww_917c9ef04e00f975.text:
[Shallow:] Yea, Davy, I will use him well. A friend i' th' court is better than a penny in purse. Use his men well, Davy, for they are arrant knaves and will backbite.
[Davy:] No worse than they are back-bitten, sir, for they have marvelous foul linen.
[Shallow:] Well-conceited, Davy. About thy business, Davy.
[Davy:] I beseech you, sir, to countenance William Visor of Woncot against Clement Perkes o’ th’ hill.
[Shallow:] There is many complaints, Davy, against that Visor. That Visor is an arrant knave, on my knowledge.

ww_cfc24cf86ead5a0a.text:
[Comedy:] How some damned tyrant to obtain a crown,
Stabs, hangs, poisons, smothers, cuts throats,
And then a Chorus too comes howling in,
And tells us of the worrying of a cat,
Then of a filthy whining ghost,
Lapt in some foul sheet, or a leather pelt,
Comes screaming like a pig half sticked,
And cries Vindicta, revenge, revenge:
With that a little rose flashes forth,
Like smoke out of a Tobacco pipe, or a boys squib:
Then comes in two or three like to drovers,
With tailors bodkins, stabbing one another,
Is not this trim? is not here goodly things?
That you should be so much accounted of,
I would not else.

ww_8cb31050f64f481d.text:
[King:] [...] Let all the tears that should bedew my hearse
Be drops of balm to sanctify thy head;
Only compound me with forgotten dust.

ww_66089fa4f4c3fafa.text:
[Glendower:] I cannot blame him. At my nativity
The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes,
Of burning cressets, and at my birth
The frame and huge foundation of the Earth
 Shaked like a coward.

ww_f6f1d4e65b036af0.text:
[Hotspur:] And I can teach thee, coz, to shame the devil
By telling truth. Tell truth and shame the devil.

ww_bc2b1df7aae01109.text: [Dogberry:] I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.

ww_f3a93252ae76a809.text:
[Bobadill:] […] sure I was struck with a planet thence, for I had no power to touch my weapon.
[Ed. Knowell:] I, like enough, I have heard of many that have been beaten under a planet: go, get you to a surgeon.

ww_298f3887c202e8ec.text: [Margaret:] Well, an you be not turned Turk, there's no more sailing by the star.

ww_6659b23525dbe464.text: [Verges:] Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your Worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in Messina.

ww_f0ff691ae64d0ebc.text:
From the black kingdom of infernal Dis [...]
And from the dungeon of the dark abyss,
Wherein the Ocean Seas of troubles slow,
I do ascend upon this worldly stage [...].

ww_ee80829c980848f2.text: [Benedick:] O God, sir, here's a dish I love not! I cannot endure my Lady Tongue.

ww_2889ab5f85490354.text: And my prophetic soul doth truly say [...].

ww_401114afff7d3561.text:
He's but a sponge, and shortly needs must lease
His wrong got juice, when greatness' fist shall squeeze
His liquor out.

ww_1efdff27768ca97a.text:
Then, boyling Wrath, stern, cruell, swift, and rash,
That like a Boar her teeth doth grinde and gnash:
Whose hair doth stare, like bristled Porcupine;
Who som-times rowles her ghastly-glowing eyn,
And som-time fixtly on the ground doth glaunce,
Now bleak, then bloody in her Countenance [...].

ww_c511383dd2b6c1ac.text:
[Andrugio:] [...] Sing Mellida is dead, all hearts will relent
[...] in sad condolement at that heavy sound [...].

ww_375719d4bb0d18ca.text: [Brutus:] […] Let's be sacrificers, but not butchers […].

ww_caf6789cf7c00a0f.text:
[Pistol:] O, Seigneur Dew should be a gentleman.
Perpend my words, O Seigneur Dew, and mark:
O Seigneur Dew, thou diest on point of fox, except, O
Seigneur, thou do give to me egregious ransom.

ww_88dcaf88c79cc2e8.text:
[Antony:] This was the noblest Roman of them all.
All the conspirators save only he
Did that they did in envy of great Caesar.
He only in a general honest thought
And common good to all made one of them.
His life was gentle and the elements
So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up
And say to all the world "This was a man!".

Lives and returned about an hour since.
At his first coming, armed in complete steel,

ww_06f96a108f63bc02.text: Camillo and Hippolito are young Venetian noblemen, just returned from the wars; Camillo brings with him a captured French gentleman named Fontinelle. Camillo turns his prisoner over to Hippolito's sister Violetta for safekeeping. Violetta is the object of Camillo's affections; but Fontinelle and Violetta fall in love. Learning of this unwelcome development, Camillo and Hippolito try to tempt Fontinelle to infidelity by sending his portrait to the courtesan Imperia, hoping to interest her in the Frenchman. The ploy fails (at first), and Camillio has Fontinelle thrown into prison. But Fontinelle and Violetta are secretly married. In the last act, however, the Venetians' plotting bears fruit: Fontinelle falls for Imperia, and Violetta has to resort to the standard Elizabethan bed trick

A prologue armed, but not in confidence
Of author's pen or actor’s voice, but suited
In like conditions as our argument,
To tell you, fair beholders, that our play
Leaps o'er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,
Beginning in the middle, starting thence away
To what may be digested in a play.

For every false drop in her bawdy veins
A Grecian’s life hath sunk; for every scruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight
A Trojan hath been slain. Since she could speak,
She hath not given so many good words breath
As for her Greeks and Trojans suffered death.

[Northumberland:] Set forward then. (A dead march, and pass round the stage, and Guilford speaks).
The Tower will be a place of ample state,
Some lodgings in it, will like dead men's souls,
Remember us of frailty.
[Guilford:] We are led with pomp to prison,
O prophetic soul.
Lo we ascend into our chairs of State,
Like funeral Coffins, in some funeral
Pomp descending to their graves. But we must on.
How can we fare well, to keep our Court:
Where Prisoners keep their cave?

What rests now? means for access: True. O an honest Bawd were worth gold now.</spanA

ww_74c5e04712579166.text:
[Zoya:] Well, upon your apparent repentance, that all modest spectators may witness, I have for a short time only thus feignedly hated you, that you might ever after truely love me, upon these cautions I reaccept you: first you shall vow.
[Zuccone:] I do vow, as heaven bless me, I will do.
[Zoya:] What?
[Zuccone:] Whate'er it be, say on I beseech you.
[Zoya:] You shall vow.
[Zuccone:] Yes.
[Zoya:] That you shall never.
[Zuccone:] Never.
[Zoya:] Feign love to my waiting woman or chamber maid.
[Zuccone:] No.
[Zoya:] Never promise them such a farm to their marriage.
[Zuccone:] No.
[Zoya:] If she'll discover but whom I affect.
[Zuccone:] Never. [Zoya:] Or if they know none that they'll but take a false oath; I do, only to be rid of me.
[Zuccone:] I swear I will not, I will not only not counterfeit love your women, but I will truely hate them an't be possible, so far from maintaining them that I will beggar them, I will never pick their trunks for letters, search their pockets, ruffle their bosoms, or tear their foul smocks never, never.
[Zoya:] That if I chance to have a humour to be in a mask, you shall not grow Jealous.
[Zuccone:] Never.
[Zoya:] Or grudge at the expense.
[Zuccone:] Never, I will eat mine own arms first.
[Zoya:] That you shall not, search if my chamber door hinges be oiled to avoid creaking.
[Zuccone:] As I am a sensible creature-
[Zoya:] Nor ever suspect the reason why my bed-chamber floor is double matted.
[Zuccone:] Not as I have blood in me.

ww_5801c2c8504632a1.text:
[Duchess:] Was't ever known stepduchess was so mild
And calm as I? Some now would plot his death,
With easy doctors, those loose-living men,
And make His withered Grace fall to his grave
And keep church better.
Some second wife would do this, and dispatch
Her double loathèd öord at meat and sleep.
Indeed, 'tis true an old man's twice a childe,
Mine cannot speak; one of his single words,
Would quite have freed my youngest dearest son
From death or durance, and have made him walk
With a bold foote vpon the thorny law,
Whose prickles should bow under him, but 'tis not,
And therefore wedlock faith shall be forgot,
I'll kill him in his forehead, hate there feed,
That wound is deepest though it neuer bleed.

Hath been compiled, all for several years
Since first I drew this breath; four apprenticeships
Have I most truly served in this world:
And eight and twenty times hath Phoebus Cart
Run out his yearly course since -
